title: Lesson 23: Symmetric and Positive Definite Matrices
objectives: Understand symmetric matrices and their properties

cards.back:
A matrix equal to its transpose: \( A = A^T \)

Equivalently: \( a_{ij} = a_{ji} \) for all entries.

Symmetric matrices are always square.

cards.front: What is special about the eigenvalues of a symmetric matrix?
cards.back:
All eigenvalues are real (no complex eigenvalues).

This is true even though the characteristic polynomial could theoretically have complex roots.

cards.front: What is the Spectral Theorem for symmetric matrices?
cards.back:
Every symmetric matrix \( A \) can be diagonalized as:

\( A = Q \Lambda Q^T \)

Where \( Q \) is orthogonal (columns are orthonormal eigenvectors) and \( \Lambda \) is diagonal (eigenvalues).

This is called orthogonal diagonalization.

cards.front: What is special about eigenvectors of symmetric matrices?
cards.back:
Eigenvectors corresponding to different eigenvalues are orthogonal.

This allows us to find an orthonormal basis of eigenvectors.

cards.front: What is a positive definite matrix?
cards.back:
A symmetric matrix \( A \) such that:

\( \vec{x}^T A \vec{x} > 0 \) for all non-zero \( \vec{x} \)

The quadratic form is always positive.

cards.front: What are equivalent conditions for positive definiteness?
cards.back:
A symmetric matrix \( A \) is positive definite iff any of these hold:

  • All eigenvalues are positive
  • All pivots are positive
  • All leading principal minors are positive
  • \( A = R^T R \) for some matrix \( R \) with independent columns

cards.front: What is a positive semi-definite matrix?
cards.back:
A symmetric matrix \( A \) such that:

\( \vec{x}^T A \vec{x} \geq 0 \) for all \( \vec{x} \)

Equivalent to: all eigenvalues are \( \geq 0 \).

cards.front: Why are positive definite matrices important?
cards.back:
They arise in:

  • Optimization (Hessian at a minimum)
  • Covariance matrices in statistics
  • Energy functions in physics
  • Ensuring systems have unique solutions

They generalize the concept of "positive" to matrices.

For positive definite \( A \):

\( A = LL^T \)

Where \( L \) is lower triangular with positive diagonal entries.

This is like "taking the square root" of a matrix.

cards.front: Is \( A^T A \) always positive semi-definite?
cards.back:
Yes.

\( \vec{x}^T (A^T A) \vec{x} = (A\vec{x})^T (A\vec{x}) = ||A\vec{x}||^2 \geq 0 \)

It is positive definite iff \( A \) has independent columns.
